Name: Hanzo the Razor: Sword of Justice

Name: Nightmare Cinema
Review:
The Thing in the Woods: cartoonish sound design, I genuinely couldn‚Äôt tell if it was supposed to be funny until 12-13 minutes in... or at least that‚Äôs when I laughed. 1/5

Mirari: bad dialogue clearly no women were involved or consulted on the writing, no one‚Äôs motivations make sense, but at least it has a perspective. 1.5/5

Mashit: Clearly this director thinks in video game cutscenes, the camera is all over the place and nothing seems connected. I appreciate the idea and the director having fun with it, even if the execution doesn‚Äôt really work. 2.5/5

The Way to Egress: Suddenly, the caliber of this whole project amps up and we get an honest-to-god story. Weird, tense, stylish. 4/5

Dead: A little slow and cheesy, not too many surprises here. Once again, nonsense motives. There‚Äôs a moment when people are arguing through golden clouds in heaven that made me laugh. 2/5

In-between: Mickey Rourke‚Äôs outfit squeaks, and his face is so plastic that it‚Äôs hard not to feel like it‚Äôs his skin that makes the squeaking sound. Favorite lines of his (because they made me laugh)
- ‚ÄúWelcome to my nightmare‚Äù
- ‚ÄúRun! Go, you little motherfucker!‚Äù

Overall: I appreciate the effort all around, but I would only recommend one of the shorts and it‚Äôs on YouTube, so don‚Äôt bother

Name: The Lift
Review:
‚ÄúThese damned machines will be the death of us all someday.‚Äù

This movie spends most of its time discussing affairs or relationships.¬†It also spends a long time explaining the technical details of how elevators work and how microchips work (or at least the writer‚Äôs understanding of them)

Oh, and sometimes people die in elevator accidents

Another example of plot getting in the way of the movie, especially because most of it goes nowhere. The climax takes forever to do anything, but it‚Äôs pretty fun once it gets going

The ‚Äúthe last guy who had your job went insane‚Äù trope applied to elevator repair is pretty funny

The bad dubbing also got some laughs out of me as well

Review:
While yet another iteration of ‚Äúwhat if Santa was actually a bad guy?‚Äù, this one deals with Santa as an entity that has been locked away only to be uncovered by miners

They never actually deal with Santa and they somehow figure out how to sell Santa‚Äôs elves for profit by training them to be nice and exporting them (hence the title)

This movie has some great, outrageous ideas: the switchblade in between the piano keys, the floating diseased hand with the box cutter, the swing set voodoo that nearly crashed a plane, the kid running up to his mother and instantly transforming into his father... I could go on

There‚Äôs also a lot of dull moments, but they‚Äôre worth tolerating for the tense conclusion

In a pre-COVID viewing, this may have struck me differently. But alone in my house, believing in community and a dash of magic is what I needed

Name: Hella Trees
Review:
I remember being in art school and finding obsessions. There‚Äôs always a fear of being perceived as naive or undereducated about a subject since ‚Äúit‚Äôs all been done before‚Äù or whatever. But when you can just let yourself go and lose that fear a bit, it can feel vital and freeing, like I don‚Äôt have to think about what I‚Äôm going to make for a bit, it‚Äôs just going to focus on this

Anyway, I feel like this short captured that feeling pretty perfectly

Name: Mosquito State
Review:

It‚Äôs pretty ‚Äî and gross ‚Äî to look at (especially the opening credit sequence), and it would‚Äôve been more enjoyable if it has committed to more of the surreal dream-like qualities. There are a couple of well-conceived song choices, particularly the last song

Really feels like a wasted opportunity

Name: Tangled
Review:
My friend Adam told me that this movie is supposed to be better if you skip the first 5 minutes of the movie. He‚Äôs seen the movie, I haven‚Äôt, so I thought I would try it out and see how I like it

Around 2/3 in, I guessed that the opening would‚Äôve spoiled who Rapunzel is, who the mother is, the hair magic‚Ä¶ Not knowing really gives this movie a sense of wonder and discovery that, frankly, never happens in kids movies

And of course, it‚Äôs not like you couldn‚Äôt guess it from several context clues, but not having it spelled out for you makes you feel like you are taking part in putting the pieces together

Overall, it‚Äôs still a Disney princess movie with a happily ever after ending, but it made some creative and visual choices that makes this one stand out from the others

This movie is one star better without those first 5 minutes, I highly recommend skipping them too

Name: Nothing Bad Can Happen
Review:
Joke review:

So this is what would‚Äôve happened if Bobby Hill kept hanging out with those Christian skate punks!

Honest review:

CW: child abuse, rape, torture, animal cruelty

This movie can either be viewed as persecution porn, and what some Christians think all non-believing families are like; or it can be seen as a red flag (or flags) for those who believe they must endure abuse or cruelty in the name of faith

The fact that you cannot be sure which is the film‚Äôs intended message can be seen as a weakness. I appreciate the director‚Äôs desire to leave the tension unresolved, despite the messiness it leaves in the movie

That said, this was not a pleasant watch, and I don‚Äôt think I would recommend it to horror fans or most people. It resonated with parts of my past (not the torture, don‚Äôt worry) and I think the performances ultimately elevate the material. I‚Äôll probably never watch it again

It‚Äôs been about 10 years since I watched this. It‚Äôs one of the first challenging movies I had watched; I didn‚Äôt know movies could be like this

This time, I felt the longing for faith, the need for something bigger than ourselves, however unknowable. For Tarkovsky, I think he sees this as the role of art (especially music). The sadness of the movie is not that life has no meaning, but that so many people believe it has no meaning, never giving themselves the opportunity to find one for themselves

The musical numbers and the extended sequences with her ex-husband are hokey and slow down the movie, even if they‚Äôre technically ‚Äúthematically relevant‚Äù

Watched with Jake Kasdan and Mike White commentary

The script gives so much humanity to even the smallest parts ‚Äî classic Mike White ‚Äî and the performances are all so good.¬†¬†Catherine O‚ÄôHara kills me, Leslie Mann kills me, Jack Black kills me, Lily Tomlin kills me, Jane Adams kills me, Harold Ramis kills me‚Ä¶ everyone is so funny

Speaking of which, it‚Äôs also hilariously nepotistic: directed by Lawrence Kasdan‚Äôs son, starring Tom Hank‚Äôs son and Sissy Spacek‚Äôs daughter

Amazing music queues: from Brian Wilson to Jimmy Eat World, Cake to Crazy Town‚Ä¶. it really works for me

I was an Orange County apologist when it first came out, and I‚Äôm so relieved that it still stands out in the torrent of teen comedies that came out around it. It‚Äôs not perfect, it‚Äôs not even great, but it does exactly what it wanted to do and is so cozy to revisit

It creates so much distance between the viewer and what‚Äôs happening on screen that it‚Äôs hard to feel anything Where films like We're All Going to the World's Fair use artifice to enhance the narrative structure, this one uses everything in its power to hide the fact that there‚Äôs not much here ‚Äî you must construct the horror yourself from the Lego pieces the film provides. Truly, I would not have understood a single thing that happened or who said what if not for the closed captioning It‚Äôs not a terrible film ‚Äî in fact I kind of like it ‚Äî it just made some choices that I think detract from making this a memorable or worthwhile experience

Name: Avatar
Review:
Unobtainium

It‚Äôs impossible for me to see this in 2009 eyes ‚Äî and I understand that this is a me problem and not a movie problem

I‚Äôve tolerated an onslaught of CGI movies that have come out since this, and technical achievement in filmmaking isn‚Äôt going to do it for me anymore; I just feel like I‚Äôm watching an extended cutscene in a video game I don‚Äôt want to play

That said, I do think Marvel and other CG-heavy filmmakers could learn a lot from this movie about visual storytelling. The final fight sequence could have been a huge mess, but it was easy to know where everyone was and how they were moving through space ‚Äî a weird complement, but a rare feat in movies like this

Review:
Thematically, this fails where so many genre films do: when ¬†the metaphor is whatever it needs to be for a particular scene ‚Äî whether that be sex, drug addiction, family trauma, homosexuality, etc ‚Äî so the story is reduced to its most cohesive pieces. In this case, the movie resolves to weirdos on the lam

Name: Diagonal Symphony

Name: The Pink Cloud
Review:
How was this made pre-pandemic? It echoes so much of the pain of isolation, the intolerance of being around people you don‚Äôt care for the way you did before, the promise of eventual freedom and the looming uncertainty that existed until then

In this, the quarantine lasts much longer, and the ramifications more severe. But we may as well call Covid-19 our god since we cannot seem to escape it, no matter how much we pretend

Review: Of course pleased to see Aisha Dee from the Bold Type have a leading role performance The film has a promising setup, but changes gears into a more cartoonish and, frankly, reductive portrayal of the lead.¬†But if you ignore the characterization of the first half, the ridiculous kills are entertaining and gross It reminds me in some ways of Ingrid Goes West¬†in that it deals with how people use social media to mask their loneliness At its core a solid horror movie, it just needed to workshop all the pieces brought up into a cohesive whole

Name: EO
Review:

Name: Ali: Fear Eats the Soul
Review:
Postwar Germany loves to pretend that they‚Äôve cleaned up their past, looking down on America whose white supremacist policies heavily influenced the Third Reich, but hate does not disappear, it only finds a more convincing costume to hide beneath

And what does that do to the person who must endure it ‚Äî who is told it‚Äôs no big deal or a misunderstanding? What becomes of them?

Melodramatic, at times clunky and ‚Äúvery special episode‚Äù-esque, but plenty of beautiful moments throughout

Name: Au Hasard Balthazar
Review: After watching EO, I figured I‚Äôd watch the film that influenced it, and by comparison this makes EO¬†all the more confounding in its motivations I didn‚Äôt connect with the story that much, the misery and cruelty at times felt like it was for its own sake, which I guess makes it more ‚Äúreal‚Äù but we have so much misery porn in the world I feel like I may need to rewatch this at some point
Tags: coming-of-age, criterion, 1001 movies, sight and sound, claire denis req

Name: The Birds
Review:
Why do people we love suddenly leave us? What do we do with their absence? How do we move on when the grief doesn‚Äôt go away, the sting hitting when you least expect it? How do we protect our loved ones from heartache?

The answer? I don‚Äôt know. No one knows, not really. We make plans, we choose the people we are vulnerable around, and we hope it doesn‚Äôt hurt as much next time. But one thing we do know: we can‚Äôt ignore the pain and pretend it isn‚Äôt there
Tags: caffie, 1001 movies, sight and sound, nature attacks

Name: The Black Phone
Review: The most realistic part of this movie was the detectives relying on a child psychic for clues because cops regularly go to clairvoyants for unsolved cases¬†and weirdly still have astronomically low clearance rates‚Ä¶ ü§î **** Spoilers below **** ‚Ä¶ and most importantly, that plot line is meaningless beyond showing the ineptness of cops since the kid got out on his own Ending reminded me a lot of Signs¬†in that sort of ‚Äúeverything you‚Äôve experienced has prepared you for this moment‚Äù way, but more so of Home Alone¬†in the cartoony booby trap way

Name: White Noise
Review:
Adam Driver slack-jawed watching Nazi footage is funny, but he just doesn‚Äôt work in this role. In a dream world, it would have been Phillip Seymour Hoffman

Once the airborne toxic event occurs, the movie starts to gel a bit more. I don‚Äôt think the visual language ‚Äî the colors, the cinematography, some costuming ‚Äî does much for the material, but it does help offset the pacing through the intentionally slow third act

Overall, a bit of a misfire all around, but at least it‚Äôs interesting to watch

Name: See How They Run
Review: While all the meta elements and the pleading from the narrator don‚Äôt stop this from being another Agatha Christie-esque mystery, the performances make for a delightful little movie Coming out so close to Glass Onion, the movie will beg comparisons, but they both have different goals. In the end, this is the one that hits closer to my comfort zone, so I just happened to like it a bit more

Name: Camera Buff
Review:
I picked up photography in college and put a big focus of my degree on it. I decided quickly that the camera doesn‚Äôt tell the truth, that it can distort reality and still look like facts, and so much of what I did was try to intentionally lie as much as possible with the camera

But I couldn‚Äôt escape the joy that comes from seeing yourself represented, of capturing someone lost in an immortal image, of making placeholders for memories so that bad days don‚Äôt seem so bad in retrospect

I ultimately stopped because I couldn‚Äôt reconcile the passivity of being the camera holder, who can never exist in a moment. Even with no camera, my mind couldn‚Äôt be fully present because it wondered how everything would look as a photo or movie

Still, when I don‚Äôt know who I am, I pick up the camera, because it lets me defer that decision and it‚Äôs consequences for just a little bit longer. If I turn it on myself for once, who would I see?

Name: Strange Days
Review:
Of all the sci-fi visions of the near-future ‚Äî particularly those about vicarious living i.e. The Matrix or Avatar ‚Äî this one feels closest to ours. VR is and will always be woefully lacking by comparison, but I know that I live a good part of my life watching and scrolling through other people‚Äôs memories

Oh and cops are bad

Name: Andrei Rublev
Review:
Starting your biopic with a dude flying is a choice, it took me a while after that to get my bearings

Maybe the only acceptable portrayal of Jesus as a white dude since the story is displaced to Russia? ‚ÄúIf Jesus came back, we would crucify him again‚Äù

The raid is so well done, the scale and coordination of it all truly made my jaw drop. Although the horse violence was a huge bummer

The forging of the bell and bringing it to the city has big Herzog energy, I‚Äôd fully believe the actually followed a traditional bell-making method

Having only watched his later films, I didn‚Äôt know what an historical biopic by Tarkovsky would look like (I was also scared that I wouldn‚Äôt like it). Turns out it‚Äôs a masterpiece that had me in its grips the whole runtime

I think there are pieces of a better movie within here ‚Äî I actually liked the dramatic first hour ‚Äî but it‚Äôs getting a sequel so maybe they can find a more focused movie the next time around?

Still, a very watchable, often enjoyable movie. I‚Äôm glad I saw it in theaters

Review: Sometimes, instead of talking to someone you have a crush on, you gotta set a town on fire Now we're gonna be face-to-face And I'll lay right down in my favorite place And now I wanna be your dog

Name: Knock at the Cabin
Review:
Shyamalan takes a compelling idea and squashes out the ambiguity in favor of apocalyptic Christian pornography. I don‚Äôt think he meant to, he just has his proclivities as a filmmaker that he will never deny, movie be damned. Which also means that you know exactly how at least 3/4 of this movie will go if you‚Äôve seen one of his movies before

That said, the performances were great, the cinematography was satisfyingly off-putting, it was fairly well-paced despite knowing it‚Äôs trajectory, and it was even tense a couple of times when it didn‚Äôt neuter the tension for flashbacks that added surprisingly little to the narrative

Overall, it‚Äôs a classic Shyamalan flick: bad, but in an interesting way

Name: Scream 2
Review:
‚ÄúRed Right Hand‚Äù playing in the theater? Immediately on board

Name: Scream 3
Review:
I yelled out, ‚Äúoh bangs!‚Äù when Courtney Cox came on screen

The action was so slapstick in this. Jump scares every time someone ran into someone, people booping theirs heads, punches and pratfalls, I laughed so often

I like the doubling, the mimicking, the echoing. It‚Äôs been done to death, but I‚Äôm a sucker

Maybe I have a high tolerance for horror movie bullshit, maybe it‚Äôs because I just watched the 2nd one, or maybe it‚Äôs because Parker Posey is in it, but I enjoyed it

Review: Lucy Hale! Alison Brie! Nico Tortorella! Folks from my comfy TV, I‚Äôm already here for it I love how much the opening rags on Scream 3, I guess because Kevin Williamson is back? Name: Tokyo Godfathers
Review:
On Christmas, a homeless trans woman finds an abandoned baby who would become the child she couldn‚Äôt have ‚Äî her miracle virgin birth

Is Satoshi Kon, whose sensibility always straddled between progressive and exploitative, the best person to tell this story? Probably not

But this is also one of the rare depictions of a trans person from this time that attempts a sympathetic portrayal, if only in the name of a larger question:¬†for all those who desire to be mothers, how does god decide who gets to be and who don‚Äôt?

I dare you to predict where this movie goes

Name: Ambulance

Name: The Silent House
Review:

Tags: house of psychotic women, home invasion

Name: Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind
Review:
Saw at a screening at Alamo Drafthouse, fun to see all the little details on the big screen

I‚Äôve seen this movie probably a dozen times, but it‚Äôs been several years since I last watched it. Watching it now, I realize why

Jim Carrey‚Äôs character resonated deeply with me in my early 20s, complete with all the insecurities and the desire to meet people more interesting than me to make up for what I thought I lacked. Over time, I decided he was the antagonist of the movie because I didn‚Äôt want to be that person anymore

And here I am, not-so-freshly out of a long-term relationship with someone who was a little similar to Kate Winslet‚Äôs character, but our complaints about one another were not all that different

Watching now, I can see that neither was the antagonist ‚Äî they both were in a relationship where neither was happy, and neither knew how to get out because each had a part of them that wanted to stay. They wanted those good parts, even if they might never come again

If we erase those pains, we erase what made us know we want something different. Otherwise, if we forget ‚Äî or block out ‚Äî those lessons, we‚Äôll just keep learning them over and over again

That said, this movie is an imprinted memory at this point: I can‚Äôt erase the feelings I have about it. It doesn‚Äôt shake me to my core like it once did ‚Äî except for the Jon Brion soundtrack, which is still perfect ‚Äî but it‚Äôs still a nice memory I like to return to from time to time

Name: The Outwaters
Review:
It‚Äôs hard to formulate an opinion, especially when the guys sitting next to me kept sighing, groaning, or laughing

This definitely isn‚Äôt a film for most horror fans. It is found footage, but it‚Äôs trying to do something different. If I can say anything, it absolutely goes for it ‚Äî I can honestly say I‚Äôve never seen a movie quite like this

I‚Äôll be thinking about this one‚Ä¶

Name: The Bird with the Crystal Plumage
Review:
The police in 1970‚Äôs Italy knew not to group trans prostitutes with criminal perverts ‚Äî a lesson contemporary American Republicans could learn

‚ÄúNa√Øve but macabre‚Äù is how I want to be described after death

The slow tracking shot with the guy in the yellow jacket ‚Äî it‚Äôs only a few seconds, but it adds such a surreal quality to the chase, and gives that little bit of insight into the pursuer‚Äôs mental state

While this is fairly straight-forward giallo, complete with J&B Whiskey bottles, it‚Äôs tight and Tony Musante is a perfect lead for the genre
Tags: amazon prime, 1001 movies, house of psychotic women, giallo

Name: The Stendhal Syndrome

Name: Kwaidan
Review: The Black Hair: **** The story kind of ambles a bit, but the final sequence is good The Woman of the Snow: ***** Amazing colors, surreal backdrops, eerie vibes throughout Hoichi the Earless: ***** I love the opening sequence: cutting between the ships and the prints of the battles to show scale, and the singing narration. The rest is good, too, it‚Äôs just a a striking start In a Cup of Tea: ****.5 A weird tone to this one, mostly on board, especially with the incompleteness of the story, but not as sublimely beautiful as the prior two The first story made me think was going to be campier than it than the rest of it actually is. Name: Phantom of the Mall: Eric's Revenge

Vaguely reminiscent of Chopping Mall at the start ‚Äî learned after that this is filmed in the same mall from Chopping Mall and a ton of other movies

Pauly Shore talking in his normal voice?!¬†

By trying to be ‚ÄúPhantom of the Opera‚Äù but in a mall, the movie has almost no tension. The whole appeal is reduced to the zany kills, which are pretty good and occasionally funny, but few and far between

Name: Nekromantik
Review:
If horror movies are to be believed, any light jostling will result in one or more eyeballs falling out of your face

I¬†think there are a number of interpretations of this movie that I can get on board with, such as the fight against desensitization of violence by insisting on inglorious and grotesque violence instead of slasher-esque violence, or the challenge to conservative German obscenity laws by playing directly within the laws

Of course, as it happens, this film does contribute to desensitization of violence as edgelords come to it to challenge themselves and to overcome their nausea as a right of passage. Also, Germany didn‚Äôt give a shit about this movie when it came out, so the challenge it claimed to make fell on deaf ears (at least initially)

Watching it, it‚Äôs hard not to see comedic intentions ‚Äî the threesome with the corpse, the romantic music, and the condom on the pipe‚Ä¶ the ‚Äúnailing‚Äù of Jesus to the cross‚Ä¶ And the ending? C‚Äômon

So I don‚Äôt know dude! I kind of like parts of it, but I hated the killing and skinning of the rabbit. Regardless, not gonna watch this one again
Tags: shudder, house of psychotic women, Extreme

Name: McCabe & Mrs. Miller

The Wild West is boring as hell, but everything has a weird murky glow, oversaturated yellows and reds, and that weird Altman humor. Also, the third act really comes together and makes for a compelling finale

Name: The Cat and the Canary

Amazing compositions and cinematography, deep shadows of German Expressionism, old mansion with secrets ‚Äî this is my shit. The humor is‚Ä¶ you know, a century old, so amusing at best, but still has good timing and whatnot. The title cards are often playful and enhance the readings

It only stops looking great when they try to fit too many people in the frame and they just don‚Äôt have any creative ways to fit them, so it has that stereotypical silent movie flatness, but those are rare

Overall, fun and easy watch!
Tags: amazon prime, frightfest guide to ghost movies

Name: Living
Review: It‚Äôs a bold move to remake arguably the best Japanese movie ever made. If you must transplant the location ‚Äî bolder still ‚Äî 50‚Äôs England isn‚Äôt a bad choice That said, this does not stray far from Ikiru, complete with iconic final scene of Williams on the swing set. While I found this affecting, I also recognize that what is affecting about it was already set in place by the movie it is remaking Bill Nighy‚Äôs performance will be the one most recognized, it seems, but I have to give props to Aimee Lou Wood, who perfectly gave off the glow that Nighy‚Äôs character is so drawn to and wishes to imitate. She‚Äôs a favorite of mine from the Netflix show Sex Education¬†and it‚Äôs nice to see her getting opportunities like these One of the biggest flaws of this film is the near chronic use of montage. In order to cut an hour from a 2.5 hour story, moments are rushed along so that the big conversations can be had. As a result, Nighy spends maybe 10 minutes onscreen as the ‚Äúhumorless civil servant‚Äù whose transformation affects everyone around him. Of course I am thankful for an Oscar movie that isn‚Äôt 2.5 hours as so many others are, but this is one where that time could have been better spent Also, similar to The King‚Äôs Speech, the cinematography is busy and insists on itself, often distracting from the story rather than enhancing it The acting works, the jokes surrounding British haughtiness and bureaucracy work, and if I had not seen Ikiru I would be tempted to praise more. Regardless, for all its shortcomings, it is a nice movie to watch, and I enjoyed watching it

Name: The Other Side of the Underneath
Review:
Confrontational, shrill, hysteric ‚Äî in its own terms, a performance hellbent on freeing the expectations and portrayal of the ‚Äúsane‚Äù woman from the patriarchal foundations of psychoanalysis, whose primary interest parades as a means to a healthy society but is, as most cultural institutions, another form of subjugation and control ‚Äî it is not me who is sick, but the system that deems me so

By today‚Äôs standards, most of the imagery is at most as shocking as an Alice Cooper concert. The more interesting parts are the improvised therapy sessions

Still, I dig it
Tags: shudder, house of psychotic women, queer

Name: Dream Home
Review:
Lit at times like a Wong Kar-wai film, flipping wildly between warm slice of life flashbacks and icy green splatter flick murders, I kept waiting for the moment where the two stories merged. But the brutality of the murders ‚Äî and the intended comedy behind some of them ‚Äî do not line up with the motivations of the character we‚Äôve been introduced to.¬†It feels like two different movies cut and paste together

If it matters, the gore effects are well done and super indulgent, so if you just want some torture porn, you can zone out during the flashbacks. If you want a critique on skyrocketing property values and the subprime mortgage crisis, you might need to look elsewhere

Name: Scream

Name: Beyond Tomorrow
Review:
Couldn‚Äôt sleep so I put on this wild-ass movie

For the first half, I thought it was a warm and sentimental story of three lonely old men on Christmas who find a way to feed and care for some strangers

Then these guys die in a plane crash and become ghosts

The first guy, Allan, argues in favor of the English colonizing Australia and ‚Äúredeeming‚Äù it, and seems to have some shady past that would cause his friends to avoid him‚Ä¶ He dreams of a heaven where he‚Äôs back in his war regiment, and then his dead son shows up and takes him there

The second, George, refuses to apologize for his past crimes and so a vague thunderstorm of judgement comes and summons him

The third, Michael, forgoes his call to heaven so he can help a boy get out of a toxic relationship. When the boy and his no-good lover are both shot and killed by a jealous ex, the boy ‚Äî now also a ghost ‚Äî is consoled by Michael

Then God comes back for Michael because Michael‚Äôs mother wouldn‚Äôt stop haranguing God to let him in. Michael begs God to let the boy live, and so he does

The lover? She ‚Äúhad no soul to go on with‚Äù so presumably faded into the ether

Finally, George comes back, having paid for his crimes and he and Michael walk off into the glowing light of heaven

Watching this movie is my new Christmas tradition
Tags: frightfest guide to ghost movies, amazon prime

Name: √Ä Nous la Libert√©
Review:
It‚Äôs easy to see a through-line from this to the work of Jean-Pierre Jeunet or Terry Gilliam: clever visual juxtapositions,¬†large swaths of conformity being punctured by tight closeups, darkly comedic set pieces, intricate sets and production design that enhance the surreal otherworldliness, beauty as that which awakens the desire for change

The messaging is direct: industrialization, fetishization of labor, and bourgeois decadence imprison us to a life divorced from goodness and joy. But¬†that simplicity makes this all the easier to relate to, even 90+ years after its release

I love that in the brief moments when they feel that freedom coming on, the movie turns into a musical. I also love that, more than anything, it is the reminder of friendship that awakens joy

And of course, I love that full automation of the factory freed all of the workers to fish, play games, and sing together; it wasn‚Äôt a threat, it was freedom for everyone

It‚Äôs always so nice to watch a classic film and say ‚Äúthis is great‚Äù without having to add ‚Äúfor its time‚Äù

What makes some of it go down a bit smoother is when the movie allows you to see just how predatory and irredeemable Dustin Hoffman‚Äôs character is

That said, the movie, intentionally or not, tries to validate his choices by showing how shitty all the men are, and that it took him doing this to see just how shitty men are.¬†‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt mean to hurt anybody,‚Äù isn‚Äôt an apology, and yet‚Ä¶

It‚Äôs a well-acted, we‚Äôll-structured movie, and I wish I could apply the ‚Äú‚Ä¶ for its time‚Äù label and feel better about it but I don‚Äôt

Name: The Woman

The messaging is as unsubtle as possible, especially once the father finds the woman he brings home to tame ‚Äî for example, when he sticks his hand in her mouth, she bites off his ring finger and spits out his wedding ring; he replies by punching her and telling her ‚Äúthat‚Äôs not civilized behavior‚Äù ‚Äî when the mother asks if they should be doing this, he smacks her across the face and tells her that it‚Äôs time to go to bed

When his son sneaks down to‚Ä¶ the father says ‚Äúboys will be boys‚Äù, just in case you‚Äôve missed the first hour

For the subject matter, it has to be brutal and uncomfortable ‚Äî anything less would devolve into pornography. That said, by the third act, the movie makes some choices that undercut the messaging in favor of an extreme ending

Name: Black Swan
Review: Rewatching for a podcast I haven't seen this since it came out. I barely remember how I felt then, other than not liking it as much as The Wrestler, probably because The Wrestler¬†was more "grounded" and because I was/am insufferable. Natalie Portman, playing perpetually overwrought and high-strung, can only embody the White Swan. To represent both it and the Black Swan, she needs to find something/someone else within, someone loose and free, someone capable of darkness. How could she find freedoms with a mother ‚Äî herself a former dancer ‚Äî who swings wildly from jealous to supportive ‚Äî the type of upbringing that creates the sort of anxious attachment on display, the kind of person who craves control over their life, however they can get it. She sees that freedom in Mila Kunis, literally dressed in black, not stretching when she's supposed to, cursing and complaining, "imprecise but not faking it." She also gets a glimpse of the dark impulses through Winona Ryder's violent eruption upon learning she is being replaced, as evidenced by her willingness to walk into traffic to convey her dismay. Though the movie suggests self-harm in Portman's past ‚Äî her mother, when seeing the inexplicable rash, asks if she has been scratching again ‚Äî it becomes clear that the transformation to The Black Swan is ultimately one of self-mutilation, or even self-destruction. It's not a Persona-esque homage without mirrors, doppelg√§ngers, narcissism, repressed longings. And being sexually attracted to someone who reminds you of yourself. While it does almost nothing to expand on these themes, what helps this stand out is the grotesque nature of her transformation ‚Äî real or imagined ‚Äî cracked toenails, torn cuticles, and of course that pesky rash that seems to be sprouting feathers‚Ä¶ If the themes of the movies are ever unclear, Vincent Cassel tells the audience ‚Äî although his motives are less than pure, the movie never contradicts them. It's amusing how his presence in any film serves as an unspoken warning to the audience that this movie intends to make you uncomfortable. Stray thoughts/Spoilers: * The hand trauma messes with me. * The horror movie mirror scares are‚Ä¶ fine. * Young Sebastian Stan spotting! * Stray paint in the stairwell like black feathers falling. * The third act pulls the whole thing together. It helps that Aronofsky didn't write this. Overall, this is tied with The Wrestler¬†as the best things Aronofsky has directed, and likely will direct.

Name: The Golem: How He Came Into the World
Review: I couldn‚Äôt track down English subtitles that synced with this, so plot-wise I only have a vague sense of what‚Äôs happening. Still, the visual storytelling in this is fantastic, so I didn‚Äôt feel too out of the loop The sets are incredible, so elaborate and such unique architecture. The special effects are pretty cool ‚Äî there‚Äôs a sequence where a story is being told and part of the screen overlays people wandering in the The actor playing the golem looks a little like Will Sasso, so it‚Äôs hard not to laugh a little when he‚Äôs onscreen The golem as a concept is one I‚Äôm only a little familiar with ‚Äî I know that Frankenstein is considered influenced by the concept, which can be seen in the film in the way that the golem expresses deeper emotions when given a flower ‚Äî so I did some reading and came across this article on it: www.jmberlin.de/en/golem-from-mysticism-to-minecraft Over a century old and still an enjoyable watch, highly recommended for old horror enthusiasts

Name: The Wiz
Review:
I was dreading watching this, because I haven‚Äôt heard good things. But I thought I should see for myself

The cinematography is pretty uninspired and static, focused on the scale of the sets more than interacting with any of the musical numbers. This works better later on when the sets get bigger/more intricate

The singing is of course fantastic, but these songs roll right off of me. This is based on a broadway musical, right? Why isn‚Äôt that cast in this? Hiring musicians to act in lead parts is a weird choice

Michael Jackson brings the music alive better than any of the other performers. Ted Ross as the lion is the most theatrical and fun, he hams it up and brings some much-needed energy

Overall, this is totally fine. It‚Äôs obviously a kid‚Äôs movie, and I‚Äôm not the target demographic. I‚Äôm glad it exists for the people who love it, I just won‚Äôt be joining them

Stray thoughts:
* I don‚Äôt get why Aunt Em wants Dorothy to teach high school instead of elementary school. Like, is it just because the high school is in a different part of town?

*I like the graffiti coming alive, that‚Äôs a fun idea

* RIP Nipsey Hussle, who will forever make me misspeak when bringing up Nipsey Russell

* The wicked witch‚Äòa henchmen taking off their clothes once they‚Äôre freed‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs pretty horny, which feels odd in a kids movie

* The floating star babies are cute

Name: Jeanne Dielman, 23, quai du Commerce, 1080 Bruxelles
Review: ‚ÄúHow could you know? You‚Äôre not a woman‚Äù The radical concept of allowing a woman ‚Äî or more insidiously, women‚Äôs work ‚Äî occupy three hours of your time I‚Äôve seen another Chantal Akermann ‚Äî Je tu il elle¬†‚Äî so I didn‚Äôt feel like I was coming in blind in terms of how space and time would be utilized.¬†Unlike Je tu il elle, I feel like this movie expertly uses it‚Äôs time and breaks apart it‚Äôs scenes with a subtle sense of pacing The film also functions as a time capsule of flat life in 1970s Brussels, which adds an additional layer of curiosity perhaps not intended originally When she picks up the newspaper and you think she might give herself a break ‚Äî she turns on the radio, picks up a magazine, and knits a sweater‚Äî she‚Äôs just like us, she can‚Äôt just sit and do one thing ‚Äî and even then she can‚Äôt sit still for even the entire duration of F√ºr Elise She reminds me a little of my step-mom, who spends her entire day looking for things to do around the house. I remember all of us sitting down to watch a movie, and about 30 minutes in, she got up and started vacuuming the house That said, I don‚Äôt think my step mom is doing sex work, but what do I know? About halfway through, the movie changes, or rather, Jeanne changes, and it‚Äôs only by observing her for this long that the change in her patterns become more and more noticeable Delphine Seyrig Is so good in this, the camera is on her practically the entire movie, and she does so much storytelling with the smallest details and gestures This is extremely my deal, I love this Stray thoughts: * The color grading for this is perfect¬† * I want a light switch over my bed! * I want the silverware drawer to be built into the table! * Watching her peel potatoes was so nerve-wracking, I was so sure she was going to cut herself somehow * Belgian waffles in the display case at the grocery, that rules

Name: Autour de Jeanne Dielman
Review: It‚Äôs nice to watch the back and forth between Chantal Akermann and Delphine Seyrig, especially when Seyrig challenges a direction by asking for a reason why her character would do it ‚Äî digging for the secrets that makes her tick. It becomes clearer that it was their collaboration that really made this movie something special It‚Äôs also nice to see that even though Akermann is brilliant, she is still very much a 20-something, complete with the know-it-all dismissiveness that Seyrig ‚Äî then in her 40s ‚Äî knew how to patiently but intently interrogate I can‚Äôt believe how much of the minutiae was in the script, to the point where Seyrig felt like a ‚Äúpawn on a chessboard‚Äù, but it seems like she was able to work in bits of behavior It seems like everyone was miserable the whole time making Jeanne Delmann! Akermann hated her crew because she didn‚Äôt choose them, Seyrig could barely tolerate Akermann‚Äôs direction ‚Äî if the film did not center so much on one woman‚Äôs misery, it might have come out differently

Name: Scream VI
Review: Jenna Ortega does what she can to carry this movie to the finish line Dermot Mulroney giving the most hilariously wonky performance of his career, and I think it works! Liana Liberato is fine ‚Äî I really liked her in The Beach House, so I hope this gives her bigger opportunities Josh Segarra ‚Äî who I learned about in The Other Two ‚Äî¬†is still playing himself, as he does in every role, but his sincere demeanor works well here to keep you guessing as to whether he‚Äôs a ghostface or not Mason Gooding is really showing off his nepotism baby mediocrity in this one. He did alright in the previous movie, but here he did not pull it together Overall, it‚Äôs the weakest of the Screams ‚Äî even Scream 3, which is shocking ‚Äî primarily because they didn‚Äôt invest in the meta as fully, so the script ultimately becomes the thing these movies were originally commenting on

Name: Alice, Sweet Alice
Review: Looking like it was shot on film stock reserved for cheap television, with a frenetic and voyeuristic camera watching characters whose motivations it can barely be understood ‚Äî particularly the titular Alice ‚Äî the film asks the question, ‚Äúis Alice capable of murdering her sister? If not her, then who?‚Äù We know more than anyone else in the movie, and yet it feels like we can‚Äôt see enough to know anything for sure. Everyone is on edge for various reasons, and the church seems central to the mystery Even when our questions are answered, we are still left with more whys Stray thoughts * There‚Äôs something so fucking creepy about a priest laying a communion wafer on a child‚Äôs tongue * ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to rush you, but mass begins at nine,‚Äù says the neurotic aunt ‚Äî the one who believe Alice to be the killer before anyone else ‚Äî to the mother grieving the death of her child * ‚ÄúToo bad she was the one to end up in the box‚Ä¶ god always takes the pretty ones,‚Äù says the creepy (see queer-coded), cat-hoarding landlord to Alice * The way people look directly into the camera, and even some of the setups, remind me of Silence of the Lambs

Name: Broken Blossoms
Review:
Seedy streets, a woman in trouble, and a man from overseas with a message of peace in his heart, and a hostile world in which to spread it

Pretty bold to make a Buddhist missionary the protagonist, and to point out the contradictions in the Christian missionary‚Äôs supposed message of peace and the concept of hell

Lillian Gish is the actual star of this ‚Äî it‚Äôs a treat to watch her discover and practice the subtleties of acting capable only on film and to put that nuance into play among the more stage-oriented actors

Richard Barthelmess seems to be following Gish‚Äôs lead in giving a quiet and subdued performance that could have easily been hammy and (more) offensive

And only 1.5 hours long?

A tragic love story, where love is first and foremost a refuge from the pain of the world

This lame fucking blues kicks in, and the levity of everting is severely undercut ‚Äî a recurring crime of 90s movies

Bill Paxton plays ‚Äúsimple‚Äù country sherif who has his own way of doing things, but his na√Øvet√© may get him in trouble

The movie moves slowly, and the pieces come together pretty early, so it‚Äôs mostly a matter of waiting for everything to go down

It‚Äôs a solid script, though, and the performances are all pretty good. You can tell it wants to be a Coen brothers movie, but it doesn‚Äôt have the cracking dialogue and tightness of even the Coen‚Äôs lesser crime films

Name: The Bad Seed
Review: Our introduction to the family has major Leave It to Beaver¬†vibes ‚Äî wholesome and unassuming. ‚ÄúBy gum, I‚Äôll try!‚Äù Gee whiz But the music has an ominous undercurrent as Rhoda ‚Äîplayed by Patty McCormack ‚Äî turns in brief moments to anger that seem to come and go on whims, and the weirdness of the much older gardener who taunts Rhoda like a schoolboy Once one of Rhoda‚Äôs schoolmates drowns and Rhode seems completely unfazed by it ‚Äî ‚ÄúWhy should I feel sorry? It was Claude D‚Äôaigle who got drowned, not me‚Äù ‚Äî we know something is off with this kid The remainder of the movie is us questioning, along with the mother ‚Äî played by Nancy Kelly ‚Äîas to whether or not Rhoda is capable of killing Claude. Much of the discussion revolves around nature vs nurture, whether sociopathy is genetic, and whether the mother is in fact adopted and that what is wrong with Rhoda came from her Nancy Kelly is fantastic as the anxious mother who can‚Äôt figure out her child Patty McCormack has a lot to do as a child actor, and while she may not pull it off by today‚Äôs standards, she holds her weight with the other actors in the film This movie fucked me up! It doesn‚Äôt hold punches, and it doesn‚Äôt relent Stray thoughts: * Love the ominous opening of the storm over the lake, then the turn to the city just off in the distance * The scenes with Claude‚Äôs mother are devastating, she‚Äôs so lost and heartbroken * The credits are voiced and the actors step out, like it‚Äôs a stage play. I guess to show that the actors actually like each other * Another movie with a card at the end asking people not to spoil it! Very neat

Name: Unfaithful
Review: Yet another movie I watched at too young an age because my mom rented it. Only rewatching for a podcast Adrien Lynne is king of the Reaganite erotic thriller, where the nuclear family is threatened by the freewheeling love of bygone days ‚Äî although I can‚Äôt speak for last year‚Äôs Deep Water Interesting questions like ‚Äúwhy do people cheat?‚Äù are at best answered by indecent proposals, and are more often crimes of opportunity that always end poorly ‚Äî morality tales that follow they‚Äôre own logic to their ruinous conclusions, however crooked that logic may be Diane Lane does a great job as someone who didn‚Äôt know what she got herself into and can‚Äôt help but be swept up in it.¬†Of course she says ‚Äúno‚Äù repeatedly throughout the seduction, but as we all know, a woman‚Äôs ‚Äúno‚Äù in these movies is just her way of asking for it As mostly mom pornography, it doesn‚Äôt really have to do anything novel, but for me it‚Äôs predictable enough‚Äî at least at first ‚Äî that it just means waiting to see how things ‚Äúend disastrously‚Äù, as Kate Burton says And that ending is possible‚Ä¶ like 85 minutes in? But then the movie drags another 40 minutes out of its ass, and it gets so sloppy for the sake of ‚Äúoh no‚Äù moments that I laughed I don‚Äôt hate the actual ending as much as some people do, but I get why people hate it Stray Thoughts * Seeing the kid from Malcom in the Middle in this is like seeing the kid from Lizzie McGuire in The Cell ‚Äî hilarious and jarring * Are New Yorkers regularly forced into meet cutes by trash-filled winds? * French former boxer who lives books and looks like that? And he‚Äôs single?¬† * His ‚Äútake a book‚Äù strategy for a second encounter is the highbrow version of George Costanza leaving his keys at their place * Chad Lowe! * When they clap for his prayer before the Thanksgiving meal, I laughed so hard

Name: The Cat and the Canary
Review: I‚Äôm gonna end up watching all the The Cat & the Canary adaptations, aren‚Äôt I? Bob Hope injects his sense of humor by being the character who has been in these sorts of radio plays before, so he is able to predict everything that happens. His jokes are so rushed sometimes that it feels like he‚Äôs trying to riff on the movie he‚Äôs in a la Mystery Science Theater. It‚Äôs exhausting at first, but I got used to it As I‚Äôm watching, I realize how much David Hyde Pierce is influenced by Bob Hope‚Äôs physical mannerisms, particularly in Fraiser This one has some long shadows, but nowhere near the atmosphere, leaning more into the comedy than the horror this time around Also, it doesn‚Äôt really change up the core story or even the scenes, so it was fairly straightforward Still, it‚Äôs a creepy house with secrets so I‚Äôm into it Oh and great cat!

Name: Heroic Trio 2: Executioners
Review:
Between the first and second movie, the world became a nuclear apocalyptic wasteland ‚Äî no biggie

Is this a critique of communism? Folks wearing red bands on their arms, and one dude looks a lottt like Lenin, another with a big ol Stalin mustache

The plot has to do with water access, and the belief that there is clean water being hidden somewhere, and boy does this plot. Political conspiracy, suicide bombers, prison camps‚Ä¶ its all a little serious

It‚Äôs still got the occasional fight ‚Äî more gunfights than king fu ‚Äî but not the balls-to-the-wall insanity of the first one

Don‚Äôt get me wrong, it still has some fun goofiness, especially in the last 30 minutes. It‚Äôs just a pretty different movie for most of its runtime

So many exploding bodies!

Name: Bad Guy
Review: A deeply twisted attempt to invert the trope of ‚Äúturn a prostitute into a proper woman‚Äù Though this is definitely the story of one man systematically ruining a woman‚Äôs life in order to get her to fall for him, and not one ‚Äúno‚Äù by her is ever heeded, I think the director wants to evaluate morality on a more nuanced scale. Or he just wants to manipulate you into cheering for horrible people. How successful it is, I‚Äôm not really sure It‚Äôs hard to forget the opening scene where he forces himself on her and kisses her right in front of her boyfriend. And he tricks her into prostitution. So like‚Ä¶ why am I supposed to like this guy by the end? Because he doesn‚Äôt let johns beat her up too badly? About halfway through, she encounters a doppelg√§nger who tears up a photo and drowns herself in the ocean. She picks up the pieces and finds all but the faces: the doppelg√§nger and a boyfriend ‚Äî her unfulfilled/stolen desire I don‚Äôt recommend this. It is a well-crafted film from a technical standpoint, but I feel like I am missing cultural or metatextual context that might help me like this more (or hate it more?) Stray thoughts * Why the hell was that guy carrying around $10,000 in his wallet?? * Why the hell did she take the wallet?? * ‚ÄúI feel responsible for making you like this‚Ä¶‚Äù huh, you think? ü§î

Name: Fanatic
Review: Stefanie Powell goes to visit the mother of her now deceased ex-boyfriend Stephen ‚Äî per the mother‚Äôs invitation ‚Äî in order to close that chapter of her life and move on with her current fianc√© ‚ÄúAlone, my dear? How dangerous‚Ä¶ how foolish,‚Äù says Tallulah Bankhead as the deeply religious mother of Stephen to Powell as she arrives without her fianc√© Under the pretense of going to church the following day, Powell‚Äôs day-trip to the mother‚Äôs home is extended to an overnight stay. The first sign of something awry is the missing mirror in her room, and in all of the rooms ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs in the house now, my darling, my Stephen‚Äù says Bankhead to an empty room Reminiscent of Carrie, Bankhead fervently speaks in religiosity and devotion. Somewhere between her devotion to God and her passed son and husband, she is driven to ensnare Powell and save her soul before she meets the dead son in the afterlife A solid Richard Matheson script makes for a better than average Hammer film, in large part due to the complex power dynamics between all of the characters Stray Thougjts * Young Donald Sutherland spotting as the mentally disabled son‚Ä¶ yikes, my dude * No salt in the house? That‚Äôs when I recoiled in horror * cutting off a huge chunk of cheese and stress-eating it is very relatable * A great fade-to-red, we don‚Äôt get those enough * Anna, the housemaid, her motivations are never clear but she always succumbs

Name: The Last Exorcism
Review: Basic concept; sham exorcist accidentally attends a real exorcism ‚Äî or is it!?!? Ashley Bell is so good in this. She has to do a lot with her character, and she pulls it off Amazing first act, one of the most satisfying openings to an exorcism movie Stray Thoughts * Doing card tricks in your sermon is so funny * Baby Caleb Landry Jones ‚Äî even then, playing angry kid, because he‚Äôs really good at it. I love how into it he is once he knows the reverend is a fraud **** SPOILERS**** This commits a sin that a lot of movies do, where it gets to the last 10 minutes and thinks it needs one more twist (or cascade of twists) The movie up until that point does a good job of showing how mental illness can manifest, and the ways in which this type of insular upbringing can persuade individuals into thinking they are possessed‚Ä¶ And then in the last 10 minutes they turn it into a Rosemary‚Äôs Baby, undercutting the work they had done for the sake of a cheap twist. It‚Äôs for that reason that I can‚Äôt rate the movie higher
Tags: hulu, house of psychotic women, possession, found footage

Name: The Company of Wolves
Review:
Fairy tales and nightmares merge as a woman is seemingly thrown into the dreams of her reclusive sister, ultimately chased down by wolves with red glowing eyes

The dream continues and becomes our primary reality in which Rosaleen ‚Äî a red-riding hood type, complete with hood, played by¬†Sarah Patterson ‚Äî hears the stories of warning from her grandmother ‚Äî Angela Lansbury ‚Äî in which men tear off their skin to become wolves and boys who ask for chest hair are consumed by the forest

‚ÄúSeeing is believing,‚Äù is a refrain said by various characters throughout the movie as we question how much of the stories we are told are true

Great practical effects and visuals throughout, with varying degrees of ‚Äúrealism‚Äù ‚Äî a wet, gross werewolf transformation vs a beheading in which the head shatters like fine china

The fairy tale elements both honor the darkness of their origins and interrogates their morals, so even the storybook moments you know aren‚Äôt quite what you know

The framing device feels unnecessarily complicated ‚Äî why does the movie start in the present day and be a dream? And not all of the performances work for me. Still, a very good¬†movie
Tags: torrent, folk horror: a study, switchblade sisters, britsploitation, werewolves

Name: The Game
Review: Rewatching for a podcast JJ Abrams saw this movie and said, ‚Äúoh puzzles don‚Äôt have to have solutions, they just need to piss you off‚Äù Now, here‚Äôs the major difference. The intermediate trip is actually pretty fun and cinematically well put-together, so you can forgive the silliness for the ride Honestly my biggest complaint is that it‚Äôs way too long. You give me 80-90 minutes of this and I‚Äôd love it. But 128? C‚Äômon‚Ä¶ *** SPOLIERS *** Of course the question at the end of the movie is ‚Äúhow could they have pulled all that off?‚Äù And the answer is, ‚Äúif a movie can fake it, why can‚Äôt they?‚Äù. It‚Äôs not the most satisfying answer, but‚Ä¶ I guess the movie could be a comment on the ‚Äúpoverty tourism‚Äù of the rich, and how no matter how bad things get, it‚Äôs all still a game to them

Name: Trilogy of Terror
Review: Three stories, all staring Karen Black as the lead role(s). Shes the only reason any of this is worth watching Story 1: Julie *** Boys don‚Äôt like girls, boys like the idea of possessing them ‚Äî notches on the bedposts, stories to tell, points to prove. Anyone who doesn‚Äôt feel worth the effort is ‚Äúa dog‚Äù. Anyone who is can be stalked, drugged, photographed‚Ä¶ any ‚Äúno‚Äôs‚Äù set aside until a better plan formed Unless, of course, the story is desperate for a twist, where girl compels the boy to do all this by, I don‚Äôt know, magic or something‚Ä¶ so that she can be photographed and raped in her sleep? Or maybe the pleasure is in ridding the world of these boys? Trying to act like these 40-year-old men are high school students When she tries to tape the news story that‚Äôs way too big for her scrapbook, and she just waits for the next acting queue so she can stop messing with it Story 2: Millicent and Therese *** Two sisters: the ‚Äúprude‚Äù and the ‚Äúslut‚Äù, the latter accused of voodoo and dark magic to seduce men to their doom, including the seduction of their now-deceased father It‚Äôs immediately clear that the same actress is playing both roles. We‚Äôve seen this before, we know this a multiple personality thing. One decides they will kill the other I love how much effort movie multiple personalities put into changing their hair and clothes. Even Split¬†committed to the bit Love a book on my shelf labeled ‚ÄúVoodoo Rites & Satanism‚Äù Story 3: Amelia **** This is the story that gets talked about the most in this anthology, and for good reason. The quality of the Richard Matheson script shines. It also helps that this one is actually tense ‚Äî I jumped She buys a problematic Zuni fetish doll that contains a hunter‚Äôs spirit that stays contained so long as the gold chain stays attached. And wouldn‚Äôt you know it, the darn gold chain falls off! This is Karen Black‚Äôs best performance out of the three, having to do all of her dialogue over the phone with no cutaways to that other person on the line, or to an inanimate object‚Ä¶ or is it!?!?!? I wanna see on the other side of the door when that little dude is unlocking and opening it

Name: Sexy Beast
Review: Jonathan Glazer refuses to have a singular aesthetic or vision. Between this, Birth, and Under the Skin, I can‚Äôt determine any immediate similarities. Maybe there‚Äôs connective tissue to be found in his shorts? On paper, this is his most by-the-books movie ‚Äî criminal called out of retirement for one last job‚Ä¶ what is this, GTA 5? ‚Äî but the realization is on its own wavelength. Once you get the dream sequence with the bunny man/monster with the automatic, you know shit‚Äôs going to get weird It feels like Oceans 11¬†or a Guy Ritchie movie with an actual iota of chill ‚Äî alternatively, absolutely zero chill Ben Kingsley introduced with a killer beat, already spoken about as someone you don‚Äôt fuck with. He has the energy of a chihuahua that won‚Äôt stop biting at your ankles ‚Äî perfected when he says ‚Äúno‚Äù like 20 times in a row. Of course, if they bite you right, it hurts Ian McShane has that icy stare that cuts right into you, I don‚Äôt know how Ray Winstone doesn‚Äôt just crumble in front of him In and out in 88 minutes? Hell yeah

Name: The Ghost Breakers
Review: Bob Hope and Paulette Goddard reunite after The Cat & the Canary¬†for another spooky house story in which Goddard inherits a castle in Cuba that everyone seems to want Bob Hope is a an informant on the mafia who says the wrong thing and becomes a wanted man who ends up on the ship with her ‚Äî it‚Äôs way more convoluted than that, but close enough ‚Äî his cover being that he‚Äôs a Ghost Breaker, who helps folks deal with the skeletons in their closest and the ghosts of their past (I found out after that this movie is cited as an influence for Ghostbusters. It also feels like the foundation for Scooby-Doo¬†in the way the house is investigated and Hope‚Äôs skepticism throughout) Bob Hope gets a few opportunities for physical comedy throughout, most notably after spending some time stuffed in a luggage trunk. He‚Äôs not great at it, he‚Äôs much better with the quippy one-liners, but it‚Äôs still amusing William Best, playing Bob Hope‚Äôs assistant Alex, feels progressive in the sense that he‚Äôs a black man in one of the speaking main roles. But of course, he plays ‚Äúsimple‚Äù and ‚Äúcowardly‚Äù, to use the terms of the day‚Ä¶¬†In Spike Lee‚Äôs Bamboozled, Tommy Davidson plays ‚ÄúSleep n‚Äô Eat‚Äù, which was William Best‚Äôs stage name, so Best‚Äôs legacy seems‚Ä¶ controversial, at the very least The movie‚Äôs biggest problem from a filmmaking perspective is the plot getting in the way of the movie ‚Äî complete with the twin of a dead character showing up 45 minutes in. Also, it‚Äôs an hour into an 84 minute movie before we even get to the house But man that last half hour rules. So many great set pieces, jokes (at least for the 1940s), and fun mystery ‚Äî including one involving an organ that is reminiscent of The Goonies Really cool lighting during the opening lightning storm, especially once the window flies open and blows out the candle ‚Äî long shadows, Edward Hopper shapes The house looks so cool, I love the overgrown grounds and the tall, cracked walls. There‚Äôs a beautiful, enormous floor lamp that looks as elaborate as a chandelier and couldn‚Äôt fit through the front door of my apartment I got a lot of time to write about this movie as it took me three days (!!!) of movie buffering and other technical issues to get through it. But it was worth it

Name: Mars Attacks!
Review: The difference between Tommy Wiseau‚Äôs The Room¬†and everything he did after is that once he is ‚Äúin‚Äù on the joke, the joke isn‚Äôt funny anymore, because he doesn‚Äôt know what made it funny in the first place Similarly, when a filmmaker makes a ‚Äúlegitimate‚Äù movie in the style of a ‚Äúbad‚Äù movie, they use it as an excuse to cop out on fleshing out the movie beyond its basics¬†because ‚Äúit‚Äôs supposed to be bad‚Äù I think a lot of people my age watch this movie with the same nostalgic eyes that makes them love Hook or Space Jam ‚Äî I‚Äôm guilty of loving the latter, so no judgment, love what you love

Name: Magic Mike XXL
Review: Starts off with enough plot to satisfy the folks who liked the last movie, and just enough unnecessary conflict to ensure things don‚Äôt go perfectly smooth. By abandoning the lessons of the last movie ‚Äî namely, that stripping is a dead-end street that he needed to get out of ‚Äî the stakes are non-existent, so besides the petty interpersonal shit, they just hang dude This is a movie that celebrates the dancing and views it not as a dead end, but a way out of the sad rut of existence From a script and filmmaking perspective, this movie is worse in every category than its predecessor. But what helps it out is that it‚Äôs comparably more enjoyable to watch Of course the highlight of the movie is the striptease to ‚ÄúI Want It That Way‚Äù in the glass station. Second place is Tatum‚Äôs striptease at Jada Pinkett Smith‚Äôs club ‚Äî I mean, he could‚Äôve given that girl a concussion, but it‚Äôs impressive The third act is all of the dancing you could ask for, the finale is that they finish. And then they play ‚ÄúAll I Do Is Win‚Äù by DJ Khaled. How could I not get pumped up and have fun? Stray Thoughts * A pile of straight boys voguing at a drag show was‚Ä¶ not cool * Pick up your fucking cash after your routine, you amateurs! * You get Donald Glover the actor, and you use him to rap, the thing he is notably terrible at? At least that shirt came off

Name: The Shape of Things to Come
Review: The shape of things to come is spaceship

Name: John Wick: Chapter 4
Review: John Wick has been a series that I‚Äôve been conflicted about each time, especially once it moved beyond the relative simplicity of the first one On one hand, the stunts are incredible, the set pieces are always cool at a minimum, and knowing that Keanu is doing them makes it so satisfying. Like, I don‚Äôt know why, but these movies make me feel joy in a way few movies can On the other, the plot has grown convoluted. And while I like the stunts, there‚Äôs always too many so I‚Äôm burnt out before the movie ends This one fixes the stunt complaint by placing them in choice places with distinct styles for each set piece. And while it‚Äôs still ALOT plot-wise, it at least reduces it down to a simple conclusion Not all of the fights work for me ‚Äî the German dance club one looks cool but the narrative is surprisingly poorly executed ‚Äî there‚Äôs a scene where Keanu falls down the stairs and it goes on sooo long that it becomes comedic, and not intentionally so Keanu is forced to act serious and stern, and it seems like his direction was just ‚Äúsay it slower than you think you should‚Äù and it made the audience laugh at times All that said, this is still the best John Wick since the first, they learned a lot of lessons that made this one beautiful and compelling throughout

Name: Let's Scare Jessica to Death
Review:
Masking your emotions may hide the problem from those who may do you harm ‚Äî isn‚Äôt that why we learn to mask in the first place? ‚Äî but if let ourselves believe this is who we really are, we can lose sense of ourselves¬†

Part of how we learn who we are is by voicing it out loud to people you trust. And when you‚Äôre in a place with only a couple of voices, you may not have much opportunity ‚Äî so much so that you may invite a stranger to stay just to have someone else to talk to

Zohra Lampert Is brilliant in this, eschewing your typical ‚Äúhysterical woman‚Äù performance for something that feels genuine, that feels like a person who really wants to be okay and is in a place with such a small number of people that she can‚Äôt figure out if she is okay or not

I spent so much of this movie feeling uneasy, feeling like I was inside Jessica‚Äôs world and trapped within the walls of her perception

Very unassuming movie on the outside, but a great subjective narrator experience

Name: Slaughter Hotel
Review:
Watching a restored 96 version of this because it was available. Wish I found the 74 minute version‚Ä¶

This is giallo writ horny, even by giallo standards ‚Äî perspective shots glaring at pubic hair and body parts for several uninterrupted seconds, multiple unsimulated masturbation scenes‚Ä¶ you get the picture

Really, the tamest parts of this movie are the murder scenes. They‚Äôre slow and the action is broadcast way before it happens, so there‚Äôs no tension. The exception is the last 3-4 minutes, which goes sweaty and bloody real quick

Like I kind of wanted to know who the killer was, but I wanted the movie to end more. And then once they revealed it‚Ä¶ let‚Äôs just say I wasn‚Äôt satisfied

There‚Äôs a scene with an open window after a lesbian sex scene that must have influenced season 6 of Buffy (IYKYK)

It‚Äôs kind of funny at times ‚Äî the cops shooting the killer at the end has to be one of the all-time ridiculous onscreen deaths ‚Äî but not enough to justify a watch with friends

It‚Äôs fine from a technical standpoint, it just doesn‚Äôt do anything all that interesting

You‚Äôve got so many better options out there, don‚Äôt bother with this one
Tags: torrent, house of psychotic women, giallo, slasher, Unsimulated Sex

Name: The Canterville Ghost
Review: Pre-Hollywood blacklist Jules Dassin makes an unexpectedly charming comedy about restoring the honor of disgraced ghost Sir Simon de Canterville ‚Äî Charles Laughton ‚Äî by his descendant, the six-year-old heiress Lady Jessica de Canterville ‚Äî Margaret O‚ÄôBrien ‚Äî and fellow Canterville, Cuffy Williams of the US Army Rangers ‚Äî Robert Young The US Army Rangers being at the castle seems like a Downton Abbey season 2 scenario. Much of the humor derived from working class American men trying to navigate British bourgeoise and customs. That and the dude from Hoboken just saying¬† It all adds up to American propaganda in the end ‚Äî it takes the bravery of an American relative to save a cowardly family ‚Äî but what do you expect from 1944 Hollywood? Stray Thoughts; * Starting your movie with a book of famous ghosts is going to get my attention immediately * Charles Laughton riding up on a horse, the most hilarious mustache and shit-eating grin, being told he has to duel on behalf of his brother‚Ä¶ his delivery of ‚Äúwhat?!‚Äù made me laugh pretty hard * Excellent use of ‚Äúpopinjay‚Äù, we don‚Äôt use that word enough * The elder father ‚Äî Reginald Owen ‚Äî looks like god, his white beard falling down his face like a painting, the bags under his eyes yawning as though they‚Äôve worked part-time for Atlas at holding up the earth * They bricked Sir Simon in like a dang old Cask of Amontillado! And by his own father, no less. Brutal * When the ghost first shows up, they boo him and tell him to scram, it‚Äôs pretty funny * TIL ‚Äúblue blood‚Äù once referred to being of British origin * Sir Simon riding a bomb, what is this, Dr Strangelove?

Name: Inside
Review: After a car wreck kills Sarah, a pregnant woman‚Äôs ‚Äî Alysson Paradis ‚Äî husband, she begins to question whether she can be a mother. More specifically, whether she could love her baby Sarah‚Äôs mother ‚Äî Nathalie Roussel ‚Äî tries to help her daughter move forward, perhaps too early in the grieving process, and so only pushes Sarah further away into solitude A stranger in need ‚Äî ¬†B√©atrice Dalle ‚Äî appears, who Sarah is unwilling to help, but who knows more about Sarah than she lets on, and who is more than willing to take the baby, whether Sarah wants that or not After seeing B√©atrice Dalle in Trouble Every Day, I knew she was up for some real gross shit, so I girded my loins for this. That was a good call In the background of the story, the French are protesting in the streets, destroying property. The news accuses immigrants of causing the riots, but we know that it was more about police harassment and police brutality In the foreground, there‚Äôs penetrative violence ‚Äî scissors, chopsticks, shards of glass ‚Äî lots of destroying doors and walls, tearing into them. The police are the ones who get the most violent deaths If I were to venture a guess ‚Äî and I‚Äôm totally talking out of my ass here ‚Äî the filmmakers want to convey the fear of the youth trying to take their baby, their country? Or, the only way to take back the country that was stolen from you is by violence? I welcome other interpretations The soundtrack is brutal noise or low pulses, keeping you on edge the entire time This movie is fucking intense and well-made, and I think I‚Äôd only ever watch it again in a group setting so we can all collectively say ‚Äúyuck!‚Äù Stray Thoughts * CGI baby, what is this, Blonde? * 00‚Äôs color grading is so over-the-top, this movie is BLUE and then it is YELLOW and then it is WHITE * Why do people in movies collapse into their own vomit? You can roll over a few inches, yeah? * Cat murder :( pretty nasty one at that * 72 minutes is exactly how long this needed to be
Tags: new french extremity, torture porn, home invasion

Name: The Uninvited
Review: Brother and sister buy a seaside house that has ‚Äúdisturbances‚Äù. Though we see small things like flowers withering, they only begin to know something is wrong when they hear crying in the house, but cannot find anyone else in the house with them The daughter of the original owner is distraught that the siblings bought the house, remembering her mother who died in the house The brother and sister show little to no fear about a ghost being in their house. The brother is more upset that the daughter won‚Äôt run away with him because she believes the ghost is her mother Things only become more complex from there, and a fine mystery unfolds. It makes some odd choices that undermine it‚Äôs tension ‚Äî characters will resolve problems like Batman, just talking out loud and extrapolating swaths of information Aesthetically, it has a lot going for it. Story-wise, it‚Äôs a bit of a mess. But it‚Äôs overall an easy-going watch Stray thoughts: * They call their dog stupid just like I call my cat * Great lighting! Great use of shadow to unveil new images * The ghost manifesting is pretty creepy! * ‚ÄúI assure you when that healthy little man laughs he is not delirious,‚Äù the doctor says to a woman regarding her infant

Name: Ghost
Review: From the powerhouse director of Airplane!¬†and Rat Race¬†comes an unusual romantic dramedy about two of the hottest people who have ever lived ‚Äî Patrick Swayze and Demi Moore ‚Äî getting fucked over by adult Michael Cera ‚ÄîTony Goldwyn. I guess it‚Äôs a twist that was spoiled for me, because I stopped trusting that guy the second he got the MAC Address Whoopi showing up is when the movie gets interesting to me. Her plus the second half of the movie is very fun and satisfying‚Ä¶ But it takes Demi Moore WAY TOO LONG to get on board, it gets exhausting. Yes, it‚Äôs more realistic, but it‚Äôs not fun from a movie viewer‚Äôs standpoint watching them spend a huge chunk of it trying to prove Sam is a ghost. It‚Äôs a discredit to her as an actress by giving her such a passive role Look, this movie is pretty dumb, but the cheesiness hits me in a comfort place I can‚Äôt deny Stray Thoughts * Scathing take down of the NYT ‚Äî ‚Äújust some little critic with pimples on his ass who flunked out of art school‚Äù * Young Stephen Root! * Willie‚Äôs death is needlessly brutal. He‚Äôs a hired gun, he‚Äôs not evil * Carl‚Äôs death is also brutal, but dude is cartoonishly evil so‚Ä¶ * But the demons that come to take the bad folks away are creepy! I like it * Sam using Whoopi‚Äôs body is‚Ä¶ huh. And Demi is immediately game for this? GAY * See my sweet boy Patrick being taken up to heaven hits a different place knowing he‚Äôs gone IRL :(

Name: Dead of Night
Review: A man trapped in a recurring dream, or believes it so, drives up to a farmhouse and knows everyone in a room full of strangers. Most everyone is into it save a psychoanalyst who can recall any number of theories for his experience The set up serves as the framing device for an anthology in which characters tell stories to convince the psychoanalyst of the supernatural or uncanny The Hearse Driver ***** A man hospitalized after a race car crash experiences a premonition, witnessing a hearse driver just outside the hospital waiting for him. After leaving the hospital, he recognizes the bus driver as the man driving the hearse and does not take the bus. He then witnesses the bus crash The horse-drawn hearse, all in black, with black horses, is spooky! Feels a lot like a mini Twilight Zone episode The Christmas Party **** A young girl attends a lavish party where they play a variation of hide and seek called sardines, and she goes to hide. The first boy to find her looks to the camera, eyes wide, and says, ‚ÄúBelieve it or not, this house is haunted,‚Äù so they wander off into the house. The house becomes progressively more labyrinthine and dilapidated, her becoming separated from the boy, and she comes across a crying little boy When she returns to the party to report the boy, she learns that he is the ghost mentioned above * The house looks cool; it twists around so much that you get lost with the character * She kisses the little boy on the cheeks a whole lot‚Ä¶ felt weird The Haunted Mirror ***.5 A woman buys a mirror, and guess what? It‚Äôs haunted. Her husband hangs it up in his bedroom and immediately begins to see images that aren‚Äôt there in real life ‚Äî a home with a burning fire. Though he tries to shake the image, it stays affixed with the mirror frame The woman offers to take it back, but he refuses, insisting he‚Äôs the problem, not the mirror. The mirror eventually convinces him that his wife is cheating and that he needs to kill her, so she shatters it Took me a while to remember that married folks used to have separate bedrooms This one‚Äôs a little dull because the image in the mirror doesn‚Äôt change, and it takes multiple scenes before the story progresses. Still, unnerving! The Golfer‚Äôs Story **.5 Two men play a golf game to choose who gets to date a woman with whom they‚Äôre both in love ‚Äî she agrees to these terms. One fellow seems to have cheated to win but the other cannot prove it. The loser walks off into the water feature and drowns The ghost of the loser messes with the other dude‚Äôs golf game, calling him a cheater and moving his ball. An angel can prove the winner cheated, and he must give up the woman‚Ä¶ but more heinously, give up golf!! It goes on from there, but I went in and out It‚Äôs meant to be funny, but it doesn‚Äôt work for me The Ventriloquist‚Äôs Dummy ***** The psychiatrist interviews a criminal ventriloquist to determine his sanity, but he won‚Äôt talk without Hugo, his ventriloquist dummy. So instead he reads eyewitness testimony from someone who have run into the ventriloquist He tells of the dummy seeming to rebel against the ventriloquist mid-show, much to the audience‚Äôs confusion and the ventriloquist‚Äôs frustration. The dummy tries to jump ship and work with a different ventriloquist The dummy drives the ventriloquist to drink, thinking the eyewitness is trying to steal the dummy. The testimony ends with the ventriloquist shooting the eyewitness The police resolve to give the ventriloquist back his dummy, but the ventriloquist smashes its head in * The idea of paying to see a puppet show makes me want to scream * When the puppet bites the ventriloquist and draws blood, I gasped * ‚ÄúOn the water wagon‚Äù for sobriety. I‚Äôve only heard on or off the wagon, interesting Framing Story: ***** After the stories, a prediction made by the trapped man comes true. The trapped man kills another man, compelled by something unknown. The man‚Äôs reality splinters as he runs through the other stories, trying to hide, but the nightmare draws him out It‚Äôs all so British, everyone sitting back and enjoying the discussion, talking in rationalist terms The ending is so crazy and intense! Overall, one of the best anthology movies with multiple directors I‚Äôve seen
Tags: torrent, frightfest guide to ghost movies, britsploitation, killer toy, horror anthology

Name: Another Earth
Review:
A woman accidentally kills a family in a car crash while trying to look at a planet ostensibly identical to ours in the sky called Earth 2. When she gets out of prison, she learns that the father was just in a coma and woke up

When she goes to apologize, she cannot bring herself to do it, pretending to be a cleaning service, and their worlds collide again. They help one another heal and voice the part of themselves that their past had silenced

The movie sounds far more sci-fi than it ends up being, focusing instead on the small moments in these two‚Äôs life, at least for most of it. It becomes an opportunity for one person to make amends and to help the person whose life she destroyed thaw from the grief that had frozen him in place. And in the process, she learns to trust that voice inside her that asks for more

That‚Äôs not to say there‚Äôs no sci-fi. We learn not only is Earth 2 the same as ours, but it is also ours, an actual duplicate with replicas of us living the same life, or perhaps that synchronicity stopped the moment the other Earth came into view?

Like Elon Musk trying to get to Mars, a rich guy is trying to get to this other Earth and taking essays as applications. And so, while she applies, voicing her life as a ‚Äúperson on the edge.‚Äù People surround her who get into business school, into university, people who are going places, and she feels stuck

With a different director, budget, and other actors‚Ä¶ this could‚Äôve been something spectacular. What we get instead is pretty good, though. It makes some late movie choices that take this down a couple of pegs for me, but they don‚Äôt ruin the movie

Stray Thoughts
* The dad is Ethan from Lost!
* Some fantastic shots with the second earth and the moon in the background. They feel out of place in the digital blue handheld cinematography of the rest of the movie
* I see the Asimov novels on the desk. I get it movie
* Of course, they fall in love. Of course, these actors have zero chemistry

Name: Dressed to Kill
Review:
The movie has such a sweeping, dramatic score. The entire film has the defuse gauze over it. It‚Äôs so beautifully shot; I don‚Äôt care how meandering the plot is

It isn‚Äôt an early de Palma if a woman isn‚Äôt in the shower. When you look up ‚Äúthe male gaze,‚Äù it‚Äôs a picture of Angie Dickinson fingering herself in the shower

Peter‚Äôs homemade computer is fantastic, ‚Äúit can hold up to a 20-digit figure‚Äù. It‚Äôs weird seeing young Arnie from Christine.¬†I would watch a movie just about his spy gizmos

The painting of the gorilla in the seductive pose is so wild. But that art gallery scene altogether is top-tier visual storytelling. Everyone is flirting, and touching butts. She writes ‚Äúnuts‚Äù on her grocery list; I laughed

Suddenly Tinto Brass makes a lot of sense visually. As De Palma is Hitchcock amped up to 11, Brass is De Palma amped up to 11, but Brass‚Äôs story is always ‚Äúand then they fucked‚Äù

The scene where two scenes are shown side-by-side has big TikTok aesthetic

It sucks how many great movies have fucked up portrayals of trans people. I want to say we‚Äôve come a long way, but‚Ä¶ At the very (very, very) least, there‚Äôs the talk-show scene interviewing the trans woman

Name: Body Heat
